Tel.: +60 405996422; fax: +60 45941013. Graphical abstract A reusable and highly active heterogeneous catalyst of the type Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 has been developed and thermally treated at 850°C for 6h. The catalytic activity was investigated during the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate to synthesize the valuable glycerol carbonate. A typical Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 mixed oxides catalyst was characterized by BET surface area, surface base amount, CO2-TPD, XRD and FTIR, and its microstructure was studied by the aid of scanning and transmission electron microscopy. The investigated characteristics gave a clear insight into the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Over 0.30g of this catalyst, glycerol conversion was almost complete and the yield of glycerol carbonate was 100% under atmospheric pressure. The best reaction conditions are: molar ratio of glycerol/DMC of 1:2, reaction temperature of 70°C and 90min of reaction time. The transesterification results showed that the synergism interaction between Ca and Mg species in the catalyst structure was the reason for its high activity. Keywords Glycerol Glycerol carbonate Mixed oxide catalyst Fuel additives 1 Introduction Due to the escalating prices of the petroleum crude in international markets and the growing concern to reduce the greenhouse gas emission, biodiesel has gained increased acceptability as an alternative to petrol-diesel fuel [1]. It has several advantages such as the substantial reduction of unburned hydrocarbon emissions, higher cetane number compared to petrol-diesel resulting in better engine performance [2]. Moreover, it is non-toxic and biodegradable fuel which almost completely eliminates life cycle carbon dioxide emission [3]. Today, there are significant demands in energy consumption worldwide leading to an increased production of biodiesel. One of the inevitable technical problems accompanying the biodiesel industry and affecting its economy is the glycerol by-production, which is about 10wt.% of the total product [4]. Consequently, the market is flooded with the oversupplied glycerol due to the expansion in biodiesel industry worldwide resulting in plummeting the price of glycerol and subsequently jeopardizing the biodiesel production economy. Recently, the abundance of glycerol at low prices, together with the quest of new economic synthetic routes for renewable chemicals, have resulted colossal interest in this renewable polyol as a building block molecule, mainly due to the wide realm of its valuable derivatives [5]. In this sense, various technologies have emerged for the valorization of glycerol to valuable chemicals and prominent among these is the synthesis of glycerol carbonate via transesterification with dimethyl carbonate. Glycerol carbonate (4-hydroxymethyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one, CAS #931-40-8) is one of the most promising glycerol derivatives that attracts presently, more scientific and industrial concern [6]. It is an important green alternative for petrol-based components like ethylene and propylene carbonates for CO2 sequestration membranes [7,8] and also a building block monomer for the synthesis of biodegradable polymers such as polyesters, polycarbonates, polyurethanes and polyamides [9]. In addition to its importance in textile, plastics, pharmaceutical and cosmetics industries, glycerol carbonate has gained increased attention in lithium ion batteries as eco-friendly electrolyte solvent [6]. The traditional synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol has been carried out through different routes: the reaction of glycerol with urea [10], the direct carbonation of glycerol with phosgene [11] or carbon monoxide and oxygen [12]. However, technical and environmental drawbacks accompanying the reaction of glycerol with urea include the toxicity of urea and high reaction temperature (150°C). The carbonation reaction has been categorized as non-environmental process due to the toxicity of phosgene and CO [13]. It was also reported that glycerol carbonate can be obtained by carbonylation with CO2 at harsh reaction conditions [14]. In this regard, serious limitations associated with this synthetic route have been addressed, particularly the low yield of glycerol carbonate and the unfavorable thermodynamic equilibrium limitations [15]. In another approach, the synthesis of glycerol carbonate was performed via the transesterification of glycerol with cyclic carbonate, such as dimethyl carbonate (DMC) in the presence of catalyst with basic sites (Scheme 1 ) [16–18]. DMC, which can be obtained from urea and methanol, is widely utilized as a green carbonylation agent due to its environmentally benignant nature [19]. In this context, several homogeneous catalysts were used to facilitate this reaction such as CaO [20] and K2CO3 [21] with high yield of glycerol carbonate. However, the possible interactions of such catalysts with the reaction system and the difficulty to separate them from the product are the demerits of using homogeneous catalysts. The heterogeneous catalyst of lipase Novozym 435 immobilized onto molecular sieves also catalyzed the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and DMC [22]. Besides the high cost of lipase catalyst and the large amount of molecular sieve used, this catalyst showed poor activity and 25h of reaction time was needed for completion. Recently, various heterogeneous catalysts such as CaO [6], Mg/Al/Zr [18] and KF/HAP [23] have been used for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and DMC. However, some studies were carried out at high temperate with a high molar ratio of DMC/glycerol [6] or in the presence of toxic solvent [13] to achieve a high yield of glycerol carbonate. Therefore, it is of importance to the research community and the industry to develop a new catalytic process for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate using an economic reaction conditions with the aid of highly active and reliably reusable heterogeneous catalyst. In this work, a series of Mg-Ca mixed oxide catalysts were prepared and evaluated for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and DMC. The variation in the textural and structural characteristics of the prepared catalysts with the change in atomic composition and calcination temperature were investigated. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Anhydrous glycerol of high purity (>99%) and sodium hydroxide (98%) were obtained from Sigma, Germany. Anhydrous dimethyl carbonate (DMC) of purity ≥99.8%, HPLC grade methanol of purity ≥99.0% and Calcium nitrate tetrahydrate Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (99%) were supplied by Merck, Malaysia. Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, synthetic hydrotalcite and 25% Ammonia solution were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (Malaysia). Hydrochloric acid (HCl 37%) from Mallinckrodt, USA was used. All reagents were used without further treatments. Standard glycerol carbonate of 93–95% purity was freely obtained from Hunstman, USA. 2.2 Synthesis of the mixed oxide catalyst The mixed metal oxide catalysts Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 (0.1≥×≥0.9), were synthesized by the co-precipitation of the metals hydroxides from their nitrates in 5M NH4OH solution as alkaline precipitation media [24]. On the basis of 10g of the final catalyst, a solution containing the calculated amounts of metal salts, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, was firstly prepared and magnetically stirred at 550rpm in 250mL round bottom flask. The mixture was heated over a water bath to 75°C and thoroughly mixed for 30min. Then, 5M ammonia solution (29mL of 25% ammonia in 150mL of distilled water) was added and stirred for 6h. Thereafter, a white precipitate was formed signifying the formation of metals hydroxides. The mixture was then filtered off and the solid was removed and subsequently dried at 80°C for 24h. Samples were calcined in air at 850°C with a heating rate of 5°C/min and dwelling for 6h. The foregoing method describes the synthesized catalyst and in particular sample Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 with Ca: Mg mass ratio of 1:1.1. Single oxides of MgO and CaO were separately precipitated from their nitrates adopting the above procedure, except CaO which was calcined at 900°C, and directly employed for the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate. It is worth mentioning that the number of oxygen atoms (2) in the chemical formula was proposed to achieve the zero-valent charge for the catalyst formula. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The total surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the developed catalysts were measured by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at −197°C by the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) method using ASAP 2020 V3.02 H Micromeritics instrument (Micromeritics instruments corporation, USA). The base amount was determined by the neutralization titration method [25]. Catalyst powder 0.10g was dispersed in 25mL of 0.02M HCl solution and the resulting suspension was gently stirred at room temperature for 48h. Thereafter, the mixture was filtered off and the alkali filtrate solution was titrated against 0.02M NaOH solution. The following formula was used to calculate the concentration of basic sites (C): (1) C ( mmol / g ) = ( Initial moles of HCl − Final moles of HCl ) Mass of catalyst ( g ) Also, the base amount of the prepared catalysts was studied with temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 as probe molecule (TPD-CO2) using Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 II apparatus equipped with thermal conductivity detector. The analysis was performed by heating 50mg of the catalyst sample under a He flow from room temperature to 700°C for 1h (20°C/min, 100mLmin−1). Then, the temperature was decreased to 100°C, and a flow of pure CO2 (50mLmin−1) was subsequently introduced into the reactor during 1h. The TPD of CO2 was carried out between 100 and 700°C under a He flow (10°C/min, 30mLmin−1), and the detection of the desorbed CO2 was by an on-line gas chromatograph provided with a TCD. The mean metallic amounts of Ca and Mg presented within the structure of the catalyst before and after the transesterification reaction were determined by EDX using Zeiss Supra TM 35 VP scanning electron microscope (Zeiss, Jena, Germany) coupled with FEI as a source of electrons and accelerated at 300kV. The identification of the surface functional groups was performed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The IR spectra for the as-synthesized catalysts were obtained on PerkinElmer System 2000 spectrometer by using the standard KBr disk method. The spectra were recorded in the fingerprint region of 2000–400cm−1. The structure and the unit cell parameters of the synthesized catalysts have been investigated by wide angle X-ray diffraction patterns over a diffractometer (Bruker D2 Phaser Germany, 2011). The Cu Kα radiation electrons (λ =1.5406Å) were accelerated at 30kV and 10mA in an evacuated X-ray tube with Ni filter, and the data were interpreted using the EVA software. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The transesterification reaction of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate was investigated using different molar ratios of glycerol/DMC. Glycerol (10g, 108.6mmol), DMC (19.5–34.3g, 217.2–380mmol) and 0.30g of the catalyst were charged into 50mL round-bottom glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer. Reactions were carried out at 50–90°C, being those conducted at temperatures higher than 75°C were performed in a high pressure autoclave reactor. After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation and repeatedly washed with methanol at 45°C and subsequently dried in an oven at 80°C for 12h. The unreacted DMC was separated by evaporation at reduced pressure. Reaction samples were analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC; Shimadzu 2010 plus, Japan) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and using a ZB5-HT capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). Samples for analysis were prepared by extending 50mg of the DMC-free reaction sample in 1mL of methanol. The column temperature was initially set at 75°C (2min) followed by ramping of 25°C/min to 225°C and then heating to 275°C at 10°C/min. The FID and injection temperatures were ﬁxed at 250°C and 220°C, respectively. Helium at 1.3mLmin−1 was used as carrier gas. The injection split ratio was 20. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties and surface basicity (base amount) Table 1 presents the textural characteristics (BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore size) of selected Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 catalyst samples. According to the obtained results, it revealed that the values of BET surface area of Mg-Ca catalyst samples varied from 9.33 to 31.7m2 g−1 and those of pore volumes are close to 0.09cm3 g−1. It was observed that the surface area decreases as the amount of Ca in the catalyst increase, which could be attributed to the increased crystallite size of the catalyst by increasing the Ca content [26]. Indeed, all the tested catalysts exhibited low values of surface area which could merely be attributed to the high calcination temperature (850°C) that enhanced the sintering of fine crystals and lead to the agglomeration of them onto the pore walls [27]. These agglomerates could contribute to the partial occlusion of the pores and thereby the reduction of the surface area of the catalyst. Moreover, Taufiq-Yap et al. reported that the excessive presence of CaO phases causes the unfavored filling of the surface pores, which logically result in the reduction of the total surface area [26]. On the contrary, the textural properties (BET surface area and pore volume) marginally increased by increasing the Mg content, which can be ascribed to the ameliorated crystal phase of the catalyst. This observation is corroborated with the physical elucidation reported in literature [28]. The catalyst formulation Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 exhibited BET surface area of 31.7m2 g−1 and pore volume of 0.091cm3 g−1, that are better than those obtained with the former catalyst formulation (Mg1−x Ca1+x O2). Fig. 1a and b are the obtained Nitrogen physisorption isotherms of two different catalyst samples (Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 and Mg0.8Ca1.2O2) investigated in this work. It is evidently clear that all the obtained isotherms of type IV with type H2 hysteresis loops, which are the characteristics of mesoporous materials [29]. This type of hysteresis loops represents the pore structure, size and shape of materials which have disordered distributions. At a relative pressure range from 0.45 to 1.0, the isotherms for both catalysts exhibited the typical hysteresis loops of highly mesoporous materials. A distinguished feature is observed in the isotherm of the Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 sample, which is the total volume of N2 adsorbed. That is apparently shown by the corresponding values of Y-axis in each plot, and explains the higher N2 adsorption in larger pore volume than smaller one. The base amount of the prepared catalysts was evaluated and the results are also presented in Table 1. It revealed that the base amount increases with increasing the MgO content in the catalyst, i.e., it increased in the trend of Mg0.8Ca1.2O2 <Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 <Mg1.8Ca0.2O2. For all the Ca-Mg combinations, the base amount was found to be higher than that of bulk MgO and CaO. The improved base amount might be ascribed to the synergistic effect between MgO and CaO [30]. The decrease in base amount with increasing CaO content could partly be attributed to the structural changes caused by the high amount of calcium, which led to partial damage of the binary oxide structure [26]. These results strongly suggest that the combination of both oxides has resulted in materials with higher alkalinity, which could be of higher catalytic activity than pure oxides. Despite the fact that the catalyst formulation Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 has possessed higher base amount than Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst, but their catalytic activity during the transesterification reaction has increased in reverse trend. This suggest that the base amount is not the only factor controlling the catalytic activity of these materials. These results are corroborating with several scientists [26,31,32], as they observed that stronger base amount of Ca-Mg binary system than pure oxides and the catalytic activity mainly depends on the nature of the active sites rather than the base amount. 3.1.2 CO2-TPD Fig. 2 shows the TPD-CO2 profiles of CaO, MgO and the mixed metal oxide catalyst samples (Mg0.8Ca1.2O2 and Mg1.2Ca0.8O2), and the desorbed amounts of CO2 are listed in Table 1. Pure magnesium oxide shows weak desorption band between 450 and 600°C, whereas pure calcium oxide present a very broad desorption band extending from 480 to 660°C. The mixed oxide catalysts present a broad desorption band between 450 and 700°C, which was noticed to enlarge as the amount of MgO in the catalyst increased, and another smaller desorption peak at about 735°C. According to the literature [32], the very broad desorption band located between 450 and 700°C might be ascribed to the interaction of CO2 with basic sites of weak and medium strength, mainly associated with Mg2+–O2− pairs, for which the basic strength is very high. Whereas the well-resolved desorption peak at about 735°C can be associated to Ca2+–O2− pairs. It is observed that the base amount increases with increasing MgO content in the mixture. The findings of Taufiq and co-workers were considered to interpret the obtained desorption profiles [26]. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Fig. 3a depicts the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of Mg-Ca catalyst samples after calcination at 850°C. The patterns were recorded for tow reversed catalyst samples with varied metallic content, Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 and Mg0.8Ca1.2O2, to estimate the effect of metallic content on the crystallographic phases. The typical peaks of the separate metal oxide crystalline phases and that of mixed metal oxides were obviously detected in the obtained patterns [33]. The presence of both oxides has been proven by the characteristic peaks of cubic CaO (2θ =32.3°, 37.2° and 78.9°) and hexagonal MgO (2θ =42.7° and 63.0°). The catalyst formulation Mg0.8Ca1.2O2 showed a higher degree of crystallinity of CaO as it contained higher Ca+2 amount than the catalyst formulation Mg1.2Ca0.8O2, indicated by the increased intensity of the corresponding peaks. As such, the typical MgO peaks were decreased as the Ca+2 content increased. It is worthy to mention that the presence of calcium carbonate as calcite in the Mg0.8Ca1.2O2 sample was detected by the low intensity peak located at 2θ =29.4°. It is well established that the formation of CaCO3 is possible as the CO2 easily to absorb by CaO and form CaCO3, as indicated by the following equation [34]; (2) CaO+CO2 →CaCO3 ΔH=−178.3kJmol−1 Fig. 3b shows the typical XRD patterns of MgO, CaO and that of Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 catalyst sample. It can be clearly seen that pure MgO exhibit two typical XRD peaks at 2θ =42.7° and 62.3°, assigned to the cubic and hexagonal crystalline phases [26], respectively. Whereas the XRD pattern of the CaO showed four main peaks located at 2θ =17.8°, 29.2°, 33.8°, and at 46.9°, assigned to different CaO crystalline phases [26,34]. Other smaller peaks and shoulders were also observed in the pattern of CaO, possibly ascribed to the presence of CaCO3. The XRD pattern of the Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 catalyst formulation showed combination of MgO and CaO peaks as follows: 1. A sturdy peak at 2θ =42.8° assigned to the cubic MgO phase. 2. A lesser intensity peak at 2θ =62.1° assigned mainly to hexagonal MgO. 3. A sharp peak at 2θ =31.2° and a shoulder at 2θ =31.2° assigned to cubic CaO. Based on the above argument, the presence of MgO and CaO in the Mg-Ca catalyst samples was observed in the obtained patterns in the form of pure oxides, with no distinguished crystalline phase attributable to the formation of the mixed MgCa oxide was observed, mainly due to the different ionic radii of the Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions [28]. Therefore, further characterization by FTIR could provide more information and evidences on the formation of mixed metal oxides. 3.1.4 Fourier transform infrared analysis (FTIR) In order to verify the presence of surface species that were not detected by other techniques, FTIR spectroscopy was used to characterize the as-synthesized Mg-Ca catalyst samples. The spectra were recorded for MgO, CaO, Mg1.2Ca0.8O2, and Mg1.5Ca0.5O2 materials in the range of 4000–400cm−1. Since there was no distinct peaks observed in the range of 3000–2000cm−1 for all the characterized materials, the spectra are presented separately in two regions. Fig. 4a presents the obtained IR spectra of the prepared catalyst in the range of 2000–400cm−1, while those in the range of 4000–3000cm−1 are shown in Fig. 4b. The spectra of all the tested materials revealed the presence of mono and bidentate carbonates at 1600cm−1, which could be ascribed to the absorption of CO2 by CaO and MgO to form CaCO3 and MgCO3, respectively, as also verified by XRD. The spectrum of MgO shows a distinct peak at 1380cm−1, which was not observed in the CaO spectrum. Therefore, this peak was believed to represent the typical IR response of pure MgO. As such, the pure CaO was identified by the sharp peak at 880cm−1 in its spectrum. The intensity of those sharp peaks (1380 and 880cm−1) was observed to reduce as the metallic content varied in the catalyst formulation Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 for both X =0.2 and X =0.5. Thus, the presence of MgCa combined oxides could be assigned by the broad band in the 1400–1600cm−1 region and by the appearance of the sharp peaks at 1380 and at 880cm−1 with reduced intensities. In addition, the spectrum of the mixed oxide catalysts shows two distinct peaks at 3610 and 3640cm−1, that can be ascribed to the υOH of surface hydroxyl groups (Mg–OH) and (Ca–OH), respectively. In the spectra of all catalysts, the presence of the physisorbed water molecules is noticed by the wide bands at 3450 and 1583cm−1. The interpretation of the obtained FTIR peaks was correlated with the confirmed arguments in the literature [26,28]. 3.1.5 Surface morphology Fig. 5a shows the SEM micrograph of the Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst sample calcined at 850°C, whereas Fig. 5b for the same sample calcined at 700°C. The micrographs show the textural structure of the catalyst with cuboids clusters, which belong to the metallic oxides. It can be observed that the size of these cuboids reduced as the calcination temperature increased, which can be explained due to the destruction of bigger crystals into agglomerated fine crystals and thereby the formation of smaller cuboids. In addition, the obtained images revealed the porous nature of the catalyst, which is believed to be one the reasons behind its high performance during the transesterification of glycerol with DMC. The conclusions made from SEM images are corroborating with the results of BET analysis and are in good agreement with those for nano-sized MgO and CaO reported in the literature [12]. On the other hand, the porous structure of the catalyst was evidenced by means of TEM analysis. The obtained TEM images are shown in Fig. 6a and b for the same catalyst samples calcined at 700°C and 850°C, respectively. It is evidently clear that the porosity of the catalysts increases with increasing the calcination temperature. This might be explained by the changes of the crystallite phases accompanied by the modification of the surface pores due to the thermal treatment. 3.1.6 Elemental composition of the synthesized catalyst The elemental composition of Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst was determined by using an energy dispersive X-ray detection technique (EDX) conducted in conjunction with SEM analysis. The knowledge of actual metallic content in the catalyst can provide additional verification to the role of Mg+2 and Ca+2 in enhancing the catalytic performance. The results obtained from EDX analysis unveiled that the catalyst formulation Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 contained 33.25at.% Mg, 24.64at.% Ca and 42.1at.% O. The theoretical values for the atomic percentage (at.%) were 30at.% Mg, 20.24at.% Ca and 48.76at.% O, as calculated using the atomic ratio formula. The difference between the theoretical and actual values for the metallic content is logical and could be attributed to the precipitation conditions of the metal oxides from their nitrates, as the preparation used ammonia solution to maintain the pH value close to 10. The values obtained from this analysis depend mainly on the proportions by weight of each contributing component. 3.2 Catalytic activity: Transesterification of glycerol with DMC In this work, the catalytic activity of the synthesized pure and mixed oxide catalysts was defined by means of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate ( GC ) yield. Different Mg-Ca catalysts were prepared based on the various chemical formulae of the possible metals combinations. The results presented in Table 2 are the conversion of glycerol and the GC yield obtained after 90min of reaction for the prepared Mg-Ca catalysts. It is obvious that MgO has presented higher value of glycerol conversion and lower GC yield than CaO. The formation of byproducts (methanol and high boiling point diols) was observed and could be attributable to the selective behavior of CaO species in the tested catalysts. Thus, the continuous removal of the by-produced methanol resulted in high yield of GC with low molar ratio of DMC/glycerol, as also observed by Li and Wang [13]. Therefore, two catalyst formulae were proposed in this study; the first suggests the increase of Ca content; and the second with increased Mg content. As the Ca content increases in the first catalyst formula, Mg1−xCa1+xO2, the GC yield was found to decrease. This behavior suggests that Ca is responsible on the selective formation of GC , whereas Mg enhances the conversion of glycerol. On the contrary, in the second formula, Mg1+x Ca1−x O2, catalyst samples with decreased Ca content presented high values of glycerol conversion and GC yield. This was not true for the case of Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 and Mg1.9Ca0.1O2 catalysts, as they showed decreased values of GC yield as the Ca amount decreased. This might be explained by encapsulation of the Ca by Mg species due to the higher amount of the latter. The obtained results using the binary oxide catalysts (for both formulae) are stratifying with those obtained using each of the oxides separately as heterogeneous catalyst. It was also figured out that GC yield increases with surface area and pore volume increase in the trend of Mg0.8Ca1.2O2 <Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 <Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 (as shown in Table 2 and earlier shown in Table 1). This observation is not correlating with the increase in base amount, as one can see that Mg1.8Ca0.2O2 possessed the highest base amount of 1519μmol/g but showed lower value of GC yield than Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst. Therefore, it seems logical not to attribute the catalytic activity to the catalyst base amount only, but to other characteristics as well. Out of all the formulae tested, the catalyst formulation Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 presented complete conversion of glycerol with almost 100% yield of GC . To this end, this catalyst was selected for further investigations of its catalytic performance. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was compared with that of conventional hydrotalcite (HT) under the same reaction conditions. It was found that HT possesses lower catalytic activity than most of the tested Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 catalyst series. Over 0.30g of HT, glycerol conversion was about 48% and the GC yield was 46.7% after 90min. As the reaction time was prolonged to 2h, GC yield has reached to 68%. This could be explained by the role of Mg-Al interactions in the HT structure. Takagaki et al. have studied the relationship between the GC yield and the Mg/Al ratio [35]. They observed that synthetic HT with Mg/Al ratio of 5 (close to that of conventional hydromagnesite) has higher catalytic activity than other samples with Mg/Al ratio of less than 5. They attributed the catalytic activity to the HT structure and correlated the activity with the base amount of the catalysts. The metallic interaction is evidently responsible for the high GC yield (100%) obtained over the mixed oxide catalyst (Mg1.2Ca0.8O2). On the contrary, the pure metallic oxides showed a poor GC yield, as earlier presented in Table 2. This could also be confirmed by the varied values of glycerol conversion and GC yield obtained over a series of catalysts with varied Mg and Ca content. As the Mg/Ca ratio was changed, their synergistic interaction led to catalysts with varied porous structure as would be noticed by the results of BET analysis. The porous structure is thought to be enhanced by the Mg+2 that form MgO clusters masking the backbone of the catalyst structure. In fact, this could physically be explained by the fact that the ionic radius of Mg atom (150 pm) is slightly bigger than that of Ca atom (114 pm) and thereby the crystallite sizes of their oxides will be accordingly ordered. After the preliminary evaluation of the catalytic performance, further investigations were performed to study the effect of different reaction parameters on the conversion of glycerol and the corresponding GC yield. 3.3 Effect of reaction parameters 3.3.1 Effect of calcination temperature The investigations on the catalytic performance of the Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst were moved to examine the effect of calcination temperature on the conversion of glycerol and GC yield. In this context, series of Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst samples were calcined at different temperatures (700–900°C). Fig. 7 shows the results of glycerol conversion and GC yield obtained using these catalysts calcined at varying temperatures and dwelling time (4 and 6h). The results showed that calcination temperature is a key factor affecting the performance of the catalyst. The conversion of glycerol increased from 41% to 77% as the calcination temperature changed from 700°C to 850°C for catalyst sample calcined for 4h dwelling. Increasing calcination dwelling time to 6h resulted in a catalyst sample with improved performance, as evidenced by the results of catalytic performance for catalyst samples calcined at different temperatures but dwelled for 6h. An increase in GC yield was observed with further increase in the calcination temperature and time, indicating the role that these parameters played in GC production. Further increasing the calcination temperature to 900°C resulted in a catalyst sample with decreased catalytic activity, which can be explained due to the probable constriction of surface pores occurred by the effect of the gaseous diffusion out of the pores during the thermal treatment. Another possible reason for the reduced activity is the partial removal of the binding water molecules from the catalyst structure, that could possibly lead to the destruction of the binary oxide system and thereby the formation of unknown species of those metals (Mg and Ca). It was also found that the calcination time and temperature applied during the preparation of the Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst have affected the catalytic activity dramatically, as this catalyst was shown to be more efficient when calcined at 850°C for 6h. In the following catalytic studies, the influence of different reaction parameters such as catalyst amount, the molar ratio of glycerol/DMC, reaction temperature, and reaction time was also studied in response to the conversion of glycerol and GC yield. 3.3.2 Effect of catalyst amount In this study, the effect of catalyst amount on the transesterification profile (glycerol conversion and GC yield) was investigated. The catalyst amount varied between 0.1–0.50g (0–5wt.% with respect to glycerol amount), whereas the other reaction were fixed, i.e. molar ratio of 1:2, reaction temperature of 70°C, and reaction time of 90min. According to Fig. 8 , it is clear that the addition of catalyst enhanced the conversion of glycerol and ameliorated the yield of GC. A linear increase in glycerol conversion and the GC yield was observed by the effect of the incremental amounts of catalyst added, due to the increase in the number of accessible active sites over the catalyst surface that participate in the catalysis process. Over 0.30g of Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst, glycerol was completely converted and the yield of GC was 100%. It was noticed that further increase in the catalyst amount beyond 0.30g did not influence the conversion of glycerol and GC yield, which explain the stability of this catalyst against the possible emulsification of the solid–liquid mixture. The obtained results are in good agreement with those reported in literature [20]. The observed stability of Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst structure against the emulsification by the co-produced methanol is not surprising, since it has found by XRD analysis that this catalyst has a highly crystalline cohered structure. 3.3.3 Effect of reaction temperature and the molar ratio of glycerol/DMC The effect of temperature on the transesterification of glycerol with DMC was investigated by carrying out the reaction at varying temperatures (50–80°C). Whereas the effect of molar ratios of glycerol/DMC was studied in conjunction with that of temperature by using two molar ratios; 1:1 and 1:2. Fig. 9 shows the obtained results of glycerol conversion and GC yield at different temperatures and molar ratios. Since the transesterification of glycerol with DMC is a reversible reaction, excess DMC was required to shift the equilibrium toward the GC formation. It can be seen that the obtained values of conversion and GC yield using 1:1 molar ratio were less than those obtained using a molar ratio of 1:2 at the same reaction temperatures, which explain the role of the excess DMC in shifting the forward reaction. Generally, the conversion was observed to steadily increase as the temperature increases at both of the tested molar ratios. This behavior could be explained by the dependence of the reaction rate on temperature. In such a case, the reaction can perform faster as the temperature increased and this situation not only increases the contacting properties but also the GC yield as well. In the case of using a molar ratio of 1:2, the conversion of glycerol attained its maximum value of 100% at 70°C, which can be considered as the least among the reported studies [16–18,23,35,36]. 3.3.4 Effect of reaction time In accordance with the investigations made and discussed earlier, the transesterification of glycerol with DMC over Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst was studied at varying reaction duration and the obtained results and shown in Fig. 10 . The figure revealed the effect of time when it is increased to achieve higher glycerol conversion and GC yield. It was observed that the conversion of glycerol substantially increased from 37% to 81% as the reaction time elongated from 30 to 60min. The highest conversion close to 100% was achieved after 90min, a time at which the reaction was shifted to completion as the obtained GC yield was 100%. Further increasing the reaction time beyond 90min did not influence glycerol conversion, but resulted in a slight decrease of GC yield which is attributed to the solubility effect of the co-produced methanol. The activity of the synthesized catalyst was compared to other heterogeneous catalysts reported in previous studies (pure MgO and CaO) and it was found that the synergistic interactions of the metal anions Mg and Ca played a key role in the observed activity of the mixed oxides formulation Mg1.2Ca0.8O2. Ochoa-Gomez et al. reported transesterification of glycerol with DMC over a heterogeneous CaO catalyst [6]. They obtained complete glycerol conversion with a corresponding GC yield of 95% by using a molar ratio of glycerol/DMC of 1:3.5 and performing the reaction at 95°C for 1.5h. Thus, the present work emphasized on improving the leaching of the Ca+2 species from the CaO catalyst by masking it with MgO crystals and thereby economizing the operational conditions. In this work, glycerol was completely converted to GC by using a molar ratio of glycerol/DMC of 1:2 and running the reaction at 70°C for 90min. 3.4 Catalyst stability tests The stability of the catalytic activity of Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst was examined by testing the leaching and the reusability. In order to justify the use of mixed metallic oxides as a catalyst rather than using either of them, the leaching test was performed for CaO and Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalysts to show the improved leaching properties. The leaching of the metallic species was tested according to the hot filtration method, where a mixture of the solid catalyst (0.30g) and DMC (18.2mL) was heated to the reaction temperature of 70°C under constant stirring for 90min. Afterwards, the catalyst was removed and 8mL of glycerol was added to the residual DMC. The liquid mixture was then subjected to same reaction conditions described above and the values of glycerol conversion and GC yield were accordingly determined and compared to those obtained from uncatalyzed experiment. It was found that CaO catalyst suffered of leaching to about 21.8%, whereas Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst suffered of 7.4% leaching of its active metallic species. It is therefore clear that the combination of MgO with CaO resulted not only in increasing the base amount of the latter but also improved the stability of the Ca+2 species. On the other hand, the recyclability of the Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst was examined by utilizing it in four consecutive batch runs. The catalyst was removed after each catalytic experiment and regenerated by washing it thoroughly with methanol and drying it in an oven at 75°C for 4h. Fig. 11 presents the results of glycerol conversion and GC yield obtained from four successive transesterification experiments using the regenerated Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst. The results revealed that this catalyst is reliably reusable with no appreciable decrease in its activity. The stability of the catalytic activity of this catalyst during the transesterification of glycerol is attributed to the well organized crystallite structure of its phases which resulted in stabilizing the metallic species of Mg+2 and Ca+2, as also confirmed by leaching test. Therefore, it is highly recommended to commercialize this catalyst for industrial scale production of the valuable glycerol carbonate. The spent Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst was also characterized to inspect the changes in its textural and structural properties after the fourth recycle. The BET surface area was found to decrease by 4%, the pore volume by 2% and the base amount by 1.3% (Table 1). This change is associated with the change of catalyst color from white to beige and might be ascribed to the presence of some of the unreacted glycerol molecules that were not removed by methanol washing. In general, the decrease in surface properties is marginal and lead to the conclusion that this catalyst is stable under the transesterification conditions. Also, FTIR characterization of the spent catalyst unveiled the preservation of the intrinsic chemical bonding within the structure. Moreover, XRD analysis confirmed the stability of the crystalline structure of the spent Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 catalyst. Thus, the reusable behavior of this catalyst (Fig. 11) could be mainly attributed to its structural stability under the reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions It can be concluded that Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 mixed oxides are an efficient catalyst for the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to synthesize glycerol carbonate. The catalytic textural properties and the synergistic interaction between calcium and magnesium were observed to influence the catalytic performance. The investigations unveiled that the activities of bulk CaO and MgO were lower than that of bimetallic mixed oxide catalysts, as they gave lower yields of glycerol carbonate when subjected to the transesterification process under the same conditions. The characterization results of FTIR XRD, and EDX indicated the presence of combined metallic oxides at the preferred loading. The Mg-Ca catalysts’ activity depends mainly on the mass ratio of the metals and the calcination temperature, being the catalyst Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 with Mg:Ca mass ratio of 1:1.1 and calcined at 850°C was the most active due to the presence of strong basic sites. Over 0.30g of this catalyst, the complete conversion of glycerol with corresponding 100% yield of glycerol carbonate were achieved using a molar ratio of glycerol/DMC of 1:2 at 70°C and after 90min. The yield of glycerol carbonate also depends upon the metallic content within the catalyst structure and the reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: A reusable and highly active heterogeneous catalyst of the type Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 has been developed and thermally treated at 850°C for 6h. The catalytic activity was investigated during the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate to synthesize the valuable glycerol carbonate. A typical Mg1.2Ca0.8O2 mixed oxides catalyst was characterized by BET surface area, surface base amount, CO2-TPD, XRD and FTIR, and its microstructure was studied by the aid of scanning and transmission electron microscopy. The investigated characteristics gave a clear insight into the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Over 0.30g of this catalyst, glycerol conversion was almost complete and the yield of glycerol carbonate was 100% under atmospheric pressure. The best reaction conditions are: molar ratio of glycerol/DMC of 1:2, reaction temperature of 70°C and 90min of reaction time. The transesterification results showed that the synergism interaction between Ca and Mg species in the catalyst structure was the reason for its high activity.
coredata.dc:title: Mg1+x Ca1−x O2 as reusable and efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate via the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate
